      \K and not include it in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $& . This effectively provides variable-length lookbehind. The use of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      \K inside of another lookaround assertion is allowed, but the behaviour is currently not well defined.

      For various reasons http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      \K may be significantly more efficient than the equivalent (?<=...) construct, and it is especially useful in situations where you want to efficiently remove something following something else in a string. For instance

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        s/(foo)bar/$1/g;

      can be rewritten as the much more efficient

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        s/foo\Kbar//g;
    • (?<!pattern)

      A zero-width negative lookbehind assertion. For example http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      /(?<!bar)foo/ matches any occurrence of "foo" that does not follow "bar". Works only for fixed-width lookbehind.

  • (?'NAME'pattern)
  • (?<NAME>pattern)

    A named capture group. Identical in every respect to normal capturing parentheses http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    () but for the additional fact that the group can be referred to by name in various regular expression constructs (like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    \g{NAME} ) and can be accessed by name after a successful match via http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    %+ or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    %- . See perlvar for more details on the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    %+ and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    %- hashes.

    If multiple distinct capture groups have the same name then the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $+{NAME} will refer to the leftmost defined group in the match.

    The forms (?'NAME'pattern) and (?<NAME>pattern) are equivalent.

    NOTE: While the notation of this construct is the same as the similar function in .NET regexes, the behavior is not. In Perl the groups are numbered sequentially regardless of being named or not. Thus in the pattern

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

      /(x)(?<foo>y)(z)/

    $+{foo} will be the same as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $2 , and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $3 will contain 'z' instead of the opposite which is what a .NET regex hacker might expect.

    Currently NAME is restricted to simple identifiers only. In other words, it must match http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    /^[_A-Za-z][_A-Za-z0-9]*\z/ or its Unicode extension (see utf8), though it isn't extended by the locale (see perllocale).

    NOTE: In order to make things easier for programmers with experience with the Python or PCRE regex engines, the pattern (?P<NAME>pattern) may be used instead of (?<NAME>pattern); however this form does not support the use of single quotes as a delimiter for the name.

  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    \k<NAME>
  • \k'NAME'

    Named backreference. Similar to numeric backreferences, except that the group is designated by name and not number. If multiple groups have the same name then it refers to the leftmost defined group in the current match.

    It is an error to refer to a name not defined by a (?<NAME>) earlier in the pattern.

    Both forms are equivalent.

    NOTE: In order to make things easier for programmers with experience with the Python or PCRE regex engines, the pattern (?P=NAME) may be used instead of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    \k<NAME> .

  • (?{ code })

    WARNING: Using this feature safely requires that you understand its limitations. Code executed that has side effects may not perform identically from version to version due to the effect of future optimisations in the regex engine. For more information on this, see Embedded Code Execution Frequency.

    This zero-width assertion executes any embedded Perl code. It always succeeds, and its return value is set as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $^R .

    In literal patterns, the code is parsed at the same time as the surrounding code. While within the pattern, control is passed temporarily back to the perl parser, until the logically-balancing closing brace is encountered. This is similar to the way that an array index expression in a literal string is handled, for example

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        "abc$array[ 1 + f('[') + g()]def"

    In particular, braces do not need to be balanced:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        s/abc(?{ f('{'); })/def/

    Even in a pattern that is interpolated and compiled at run-time, literal code blocks will be compiled once, at perl compile time; the following prints "ABCD":

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        print "D";
    my $qr = qr/(?{ BEGIN { print "A" } })/;
    my $foo = "foo";
    /$foo$qr(?{ BEGIN { print "B" } })/;
    BEGIN { print "C" }

    In patterns where the text of the code is derived from run-time information rather than appearing literally in a source code /pattern/, the code is compiled at the same time that the pattern is compiled, and for reasons of security, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    use re 'eval' must be in scope. This is to stop user-supplied patterns containing code snippets from being executable.

    In situations where you need to enable this with http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    use re 'eval' , you should also have taint checking enabled. Better yet, use the carefully constrained evaluation within a Safe compartment. See perlsec for details about both these mechanisms.

    From the viewpoint of parsing, lexical variable scope and closures,

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        /AAA(?{ BBB })CCC/

    behaves approximately like

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        /AAA/ && do { BBB } && /CCC/

    Similarly,

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        qr/AAA(?{ BBB })CCC/

    behaves approximately like

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        sub { /AAA/ && do { BBB } && /CCC/ }

    In particular:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        { my $i = 1; $r = qr/(?{ print $i })/ }
    my $i = 2;
    /$r/; # prints "1"

    Inside a (?{...}) block, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $_ refers to the string the regular expression is matching against. You can also use pos() to know what is the current position of matching within this string.

    The code block introduces a new scope from the perspective of lexical variable declarations, but not from the perspective of local and similar localizing behaviours. So later code blocks within the same pattern will still see the values which were localized in earlier blocks. These accumulated localizations are undone either at the end of a successful match, or if the assertion is backtracked (compare Backtracking). For example,

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

      $_ = 'a' x 8;
  m<
          (?{ $cnt = 0 })               # Initialize $cnt.
          (
              a
              (?{
                      local $cnt = $cnt + 1;  # Update $cnt,
                                                                      # backtracking-safe.
              })
          )*
          aaaa
          (?{ $res = $cnt })            # On success copy to
                                                                      # non-localized location.
      >x;

    will initially increment http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $cnt up to 8; then during backtracking, its value will be unwound back to 4, which is the value assigned to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $res . At the end of the regex execution, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $cnt will be wound back to its initial value of 0.

    This assertion may be used as the condition in a

    1.     (?(condition)yes-pattern|no-pattern)

    switch. If not used in this way, the result of evaluation of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    code is put into the special variable http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $^R . This happens immediately, so http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $^R can be used from other (?{ code }) assertions inside the same regular expression.

    The assignment to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $^R above is properly localized, so the old value of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $^R is restored if the assertion is backtracked; compare Backtracking.

    Note that the special variable http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $^N is particularly useful with code blocks to capture the results of submatches in variables without having to keep track of the number of nested parentheses. For example:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

      $_ = "The brown fox jumps over the lazy dog";
  /the (\S+)(?{ $color = $^N }) (\S+)(?{ $animal = $^N })/i;
  print "color = $color, animal = $animal\n";
  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    (??{ code })

    WARNING: Using this feature safely requires that you understand its limitations. Code executed that has side effects may not perform identically from version to version due to the effect of future optimisations in the regex engine. For more information on this, see Embedded Code Execution Frequency.

    This is a "postponed" regular subexpression. It behaves in exactly the same way as a (?{ code }) code block as described above, except that its return value, rather than being assigned to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $^R , is treated as a pattern, compiled if it's a string (or used as-is if its a qr// object), then matched as if it were inserted instead of this construct.

    During the matching of this sub-pattern, it has its own set of captures which are valid during the sub-match, but are discarded once control returns to the main pattern. For example, the following matches, with the inner pattern capturing "B" and matching "BB", while the outer pattern captures "A";

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        my $inner = '(.)\1';
    "ABBA" =~ /^(.)(??{ $inner })\1/;
    print $1; # prints "A";

    Note that this means that there is no way for the inner pattern to refer to a capture group defined outside. (The code block itself can use http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $1 , etc., to refer to the enclosing pattern's capture groups.) Thus, although

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        ('a' x 100)=~/(??{'(.)' x 100})/

    will match, it will not set http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $1 on exit.

    The following pattern matches a parenthesized group:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

     $re = qr{
                        \(
                        (?:
                              (?> [^()]+ )  # Non-parens without backtracking
                          |
                              (??{ $re })   # Group with matching parens
                        )*
                        \)
                  }x;

    See also (?PARNO) for a different, more efficient way to accomplish the same task.

    Executing a postponed regular expression 50 times without consuming any input string will result in a fatal error. The maximum depth is compiled into perl, so changing it requires a custom build.

  • (?PARNO) (?-PARNO) (?+PARNO) (?R) (?0)

    Recursive subpattern. Treat the contents of a given capture buffer in the current pattern as an independent subpattern and attempt to match it at the current position in the string. Information about capture state from the caller for things like backreferences is available to the subpattern, but capture buffers set by the subpattern are not visible to the caller.

    Similar to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    (??{ code }) except that it does not involve executing any code or potentially compiling a returned pattern string; instead it treats the part of the current pattern contained within a specified capture group as an independent pattern that must match at the current position. Also different is the treatment of capture buffers, unlike http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    (??{ code }) recursive patterns have access to their caller's match state, so one can use backreferences safely.

    PARNO is a sequence of digits (not starting with 0) whose value reflects the paren-number of the capture group to recurse to. (?R) recurses to the beginning of the whole pattern. (?0) is an alternate syntax for (?R). If PARNO is preceded by a plus or minus sign then it is assumed to be relative, with negative numbers indicating preceding capture groups and positive ones following. Thus (?-1) refers to the most recently declared group, and (?+1) indicates the next group to be declared. Note that the counting for relative recursion differs from that of relative backreferences, in that with recursion unclosed groups are included.

    The following pattern matches a function http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    foo() which may contain balanced parentheses as the argument.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

      $re = qr{ (                   # paren group 1 (full function)
                            foo
                            (                 # paren group 2 (parens)
                                \(
                                    (             # paren group 3 (contents of parens)
                                    (?:
                                      (?> [^()]+ ) # Non-parens without backtracking
                                    |
                                      (?2)         # Recurse to start of paren group 2
                                    )*
                                    )
                                \)
                            )
                        )
                    }x;

    If the pattern was used as follows

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        'foo(bar(baz)+baz(bop))'=~/$re/
        and print "\$1 = $1\n",
                  "\$2 = $2\n",
                  "\$3 = $3\n";

    the output produced should be the following:

    1.     $1 = foo(bar(baz)+baz(bop))
    2.     $2 = (bar(baz)+baz(bop))
    3.     $3 = bar(baz)+baz(bop)

    If there is no corresponding capture group defined, then it is a fatal error. Recursing deeper than 50 times without consuming any input string will also result in a fatal error. The maximum depth is compiled into perl, so changing it requires a custom build.

    The following shows how using negative indexing can make it easier to embed recursive patterns inside of a qr// construct for later use:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        my $parens = qr/(\((?:[^()]++|(?-1))*+\))/;
    if (/foo $parens \s+ \+ \s+ bar $parens/x) {
       # do something here...
    }

    Note that this pattern does not behave the same way as the equivalent PCRE or Python construct of the same form. In Perl you can backtrack into a recursed group, in PCRE and Python the recursed into group is treated as atomic. Also, modifiers are resolved at compile time, so constructs like (?i:(?1)) or (?:(?i)(?1)) do not affect how the sub-pattern will be processed.

  • (?&NAME)

    Recurse to a named subpattern. Identical to (?PARNO) except that the parenthesis to recurse to is determined by name. If multiple parentheses have the same name, then it recurses to the leftmost.

    It is an error to refer to a name that is not declared somewhere in the pattern.

    NOTE: In order to make things easier for programmers with experience with the Python or PCRE regex engines the pattern (?P>NAME) may be used instead of (?&NAME).

  • (?(condition)yes-pattern|no-pattern)
  • (?(condition)yes-pattern)

    Conditional expression. Matches http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    yes-pattern if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    condition yields a true value, matches no-pattern otherwise. A missing pattern always matches.

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    (condition) should be one of:

    • an integer in parentheses

      (which is valid if the corresponding pair of parentheses matched);

    • a lookahead/lookbehind/evaluate zero-width assertion;
    • a name in angle brackets or single quotes

      (which is valid if a group with the given name matched);

    • the special symbol http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (R)

      (true when evaluated inside of recursion or eval). Additionally the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      R may be followed by a number, (which will be true when evaluated when recursing inside of the appropriate group), or by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      &NAME , in which case it will be true only when evaluated during recursion in the named group.

    Here's a summary of the possible predicates:

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (1) http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (2) ...

      Checks if the numbered capturing group has matched something.

    • (<NAME>) ('NAME')

      Checks if a group with the given name has matched something.

    • (?=...) (?!...) (?<=...) (?<!...)

      Checks whether the pattern matches (or does not match, for the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      "!" variants).

    • (?{ CODE })

      Treats the return value of the code block as the condition.

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (R)

      Checks if the expression has been evaluated inside of recursion.

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (R1) http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (R2) ...

      Checks if the expression has been evaluated while executing directly inside of the n-th capture group. This check is the regex equivalent of

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        if ((caller(0))[3] eq 'subname') { ... }

      In other words, it does not check the full recursion stack.

    • (R&NAME)

      Similar to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (R1) , this predicate checks to see if we're executing directly inside of the leftmost group with a given name (this is the same logic used by (?&NAME) to disambiguate). It does not check the full stack, but only the name of the innermost active recursion.

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (DEFINE)

      In this case, the yes-pattern is never directly executed, and no no-pattern is allowed. Similar in spirit to (?{0}) but more efficient. See below for details.

    For example:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        m{ ( \( )?
              [^()]+
              (?(1) \) )
          }x

    matches a chunk of non-parentheses, possibly included in parentheses themselves.

    A special form is the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    (DEFINE) predicate, which never executes its yes-pattern directly, and does not allow a no-pattern. This allows one to define subpatterns which will be executed only by the recursion mechanism. This way, you can define a set of regular expression rules that can be bundled into any pattern you choose.

    It is recommended that for this usage you put the DEFINE block at the end of the pattern, and that you name any subpatterns defined within it.

    Also, it's worth noting that patterns defined this way probably will not be as efficient, as the optimizer is not very clever about handling them.

    An example of how this might be used is as follows:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

      /(?<NAME>(?&NAME_PAT))(?<ADDR>(?&ADDRESS_PAT))
      (?(DEFINE)
          (?<NAME_PAT>....)
          (?<ADDRESS_PAT>....)
      )/x

    Note that capture groups matched inside of recursion are not accessible after the recursion returns, so the extra layer of capturing groups is necessary. Thus http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $+{NAME_PAT} would not be defined even though http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $+{NAME} would be.

    Finally, keep in mind that subpatterns created inside a DEFINE block count towards the absolute and relative number of captures, so this:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        my @captures = "a" =~ /(.)                  # First capture
                                                      (?(DEFINE)
                                                              (?<EXAMPLE> 1 )  # Second capture
                                                      )/x;
    say scalar @captures;

    Will output 2, not 1. This is particularly important if you intend to compile the definitions with the qr// operator, and later interpolate them in another pattern.

  • (?>pattern)

    An "independent" subexpression, one which matches the substring that a standalone http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    pattern would match if anchored at the given position, and it matches nothing other than this substring. This construct is useful for optimizations of what would otherwise be "eternal" matches, because it will not backtrack (see Backtracking). It may also be useful in places where the "grab all you can, and do not give anything back" semantic is desirable.

    For example: ^(?>a*)ab will never match, since (?>a*) (anchored at the beginning of string, as above) will match all characters http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a at the beginning of string, leaving no http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ab to match. In contrast, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a*ab will match the same as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a+b , since the match of the subgroup http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a* is influenced by the following group http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ab (see Backtracking). In particular, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a* inside http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a*ab will match fewer characters than a standalone http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a* , since this makes the tail match.

    (?>pattern) does not disable backtracking altogether once it has matched. It is still possible to backtrack past the construct, but not into it. So ((?>a*)|(?>b*))ar will still match "bar".

    An effect similar to (?>pattern) may be achieved by writing (?=(pattern))\g{-1}. This matches the same substring as a standalone http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a+ , and the following http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    \g{-1} eats the matched string; it therefore makes a zero-length assertion into an analogue of (?>...). (The difference between these two constructs is that the second one uses a capturing group, thus shifting ordinals of backreferences in the rest of a regular expression.)

    Consider this pattern:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        m{ \(
                    (
                        [^()]+           # x+
                    |
                        \( [^()]* \)
                    )+
              \)
          }x

    That will efficiently match a nonempty group with matching parentheses two levels deep or less. However, if there is no such group, it will take virtually forever on a long string. That's because there are so many different ways to split a long string into several substrings. This is what (.+)+ is doing, and (.+)+ is similar to a subpattern of the above pattern. Consider how the pattern above detects no-match on ((()aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa in several seconds, but that each extra letter doubles this time. This exponential performance will make it appear that your program has hung. However, a tiny change to this pattern

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        m{ \(
                    (
                        (?> [^()]+ )        # change x+ above to (?> x+ )
                    |
                        \( [^()]* \)
                    )+
              \)
          }x

    which uses (?>...) matches exactly when the one above does (verifying this yourself would be a productive exercise), but finishes in a fourth the time when used on a similar string with 1000000 http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a s. Be aware, however, that, when this construct is followed by a quantifier, it currently triggers a warning message under the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    use warnings pragma or -w switch saying it http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    "matches null string many times in regex" .

    On simple groups, such as the pattern (?> [^()]+ ), a comparable effect may be achieved by negative lookahead, as in [^()]+ (?! [^()] ). This was only 4 times slower on a string with 1000000 http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    a s.

    The "grab all you can, and do not give anything back" semantic is desirable in many situations where on the first sight a simple http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ()* looks like the correct solution. Suppose we parse text with comments being delimited by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    "#" followed by some optional (horizontal) whitespace. Contrary to its appearance, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    #[ \t]* is not the correct subexpression to match the comment delimiter, because it may "give up" some whitespace if the remainder of the pattern can be made to match that way. The correct answer is either one of these:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        (?>#[ \t]*)
        #[ \t]*(?![ \t])

    For example, to grab non-empty comments into http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    $1 , one should use either one of these:

    http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

        / (?> \# [ \t]* ) (        .+ ) /x;
    /     \# [ \t]*   ( [^ \t] .* ) /x;

    Which one you pick depends on which of these expressions better reflects the above specification of comments.

    In some literature this construct is called "atomic matching" or "possessive matching".

    Possessive quantifiers are equivalent to putting the item they are applied to inside of one of these constructs. The following equivalences apply:

    1.     Quantifier Form     Bracketing Form
    2.     ---------------     ---------------
    3.     PAT*+               (?>PAT*)
    4.     PAT++               (?>PAT+)
    5.     PAT?+               (?>PAT?)
    6.     PAT{min,max}+       (?>PAT{min,max})
  • (?[ ])

    See Extended Bracketed Character Classes in perlrecharclass.

Special Backtracking Control Verbs

These special patterns are generally of the form (*VERB:ARG). Unless otherwise stated the ARG argument is optional; in some cases, it is mandatory.

Any pattern containing a special backtracking verb that allows an argument has the special behaviour that when executed it sets the current package's http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGERROR and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGMARK variables. When doing so the following rules apply:

On failure, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGERROR variable will be set to the ARG value of the verb pattern, if the verb was involved in the failure of the match. If the ARG part of the pattern was omitted, then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGERROR will be set to the name of the last (*MARK:NAME) pattern executed, or to TRUE if there was none. Also, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGMARK variable will be set to FALSE.

On a successful match, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGERROR variable will be set to FALSE, and the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGMARK variable will be set to the name of the last (*MARK:NAME) pattern executed. See the explanation for the (*MARK:NAME) verb below for more details.

NOTE: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGERROR and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGMARK are not magic variables like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$1 and most other regex-related variables. They are not local to a scope, nor readonly, but instead are volatile package variables similar to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$AUTOLOAD . Use local to localize changes to them to a specific scope if necessary.

If a pattern does not contain a special backtracking verb that allows an argument, then http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGERROR and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$REGMARK are not touched at all.

  • Verbs
    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) (*PRUNE:NAME)

      This zero-width pattern prunes the backtracking tree at the current point when backtracked into on failure. Consider the pattern A (*PRUNE) B, where A and B are complex patterns. Until the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) verb is reached, A may backtrack as necessary to match. Once it is reached, matching continues in B, which may also backtrack as necessary; however, should B not match, then no further backtracking will take place, and the pattern will fail outright at the current starting position.

      The following example counts all the possible matching strings in a pattern (without actually matching any of them).

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

          'aaab' =~ /a+b?(?{print "$&\n"; $count++})(*FAIL)/;
    print "Count=$count\n";

      which produces:

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

          aaab
    aaa
    aa
    a
    aab
    aa
    a
    ab
    a
    Count=9

      If we add a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) before the count like the following

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

          'aaab' =~ /a+b?(*PRUNE)(?{print "$&\n"; $count++})(*FAIL)/;
    print "Count=$count\n";

      we prevent backtracking and find the count of the longest matching string at each matching starting point like so:

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

          aaab
    aab
    ab
    Count=3

      Any number of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) assertions may be used in a pattern.

      See also (?>pattern) and possessive quantifiers for other ways to control backtracking. In some cases, the use of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) can be replaced with a (?>pattern) with no functional difference; however, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) can be used to handle cases that cannot be expressed using a (?>pattern) alone.

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) (*SKIP:NAME)

      This zero-width pattern is similar to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) , except that on failure it also signifies that whatever text that was matched leading up to the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) pattern being executed cannot be part of any match of this pattern. This effectively means that the regex engine "skips" forward to this position on failure and tries to match again, (assuming that there is sufficient room to match).

      The name of the (*SKIP:NAME) pattern has special significance. If a (*MARK:NAME) was encountered while matching, then it is that position which is used as the "skip point". If no http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*MARK) of that name was encountered, then the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) operator has no effect. When used without a name the "skip point" is where the match point was when executing the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) pattern.

      Compare the following to the examples in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) ; note the string is twice as long:

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

       'aaabaaab' =~ /a+b?(*SKIP)(?{print "$&\n"; $count++})(*FAIL)/;
 print "Count=$count\n";

      outputs

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

          aaab
    aaab
    Count=2

      Once the 'aaab' at the start of the string has matched, and the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) executed, the next starting point will be where the cursor was when the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) was executed.

    • (*MARK:NAME) (*:NAME)

      This zero-width pattern can be used to mark the point reached in a string when a certain part of the pattern has been successfully matched. This mark may be given a name. A later http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) pattern will then skip forward to that point if backtracked into on failure. Any number of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*MARK) patterns are allowed, and the NAME portion may be duplicated.

      In addition to interacting with the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) pattern, (*MARK:NAME) can be used to "label" a pattern branch, so that after matching, the program can determine which branches of the pattern were involved in the match.

      When a match is successful, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $REGMARK variable will be set to the name of the most recently executed (*MARK:NAME) that was involved in the match.

      This can be used to determine which branch of a pattern was matched without using a separate capture group for each branch, which in turn can result in a performance improvement, as perl cannot optimize http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      /(?:(x)|(y)|(z))/ as efficiently as something like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      /(?:x(*MARK:x)|y(*MARK:y)|z(*MARK:z))/ .

      When a match has failed, and unless another verb has been involved in failing the match and has provided its own name to use, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $REGERROR variable will be set to the name of the most recently executed (*MARK:NAME).

      See (*SKIP) for more details.

      As a shortcut (*MARK:NAME) can be written (*:NAME).

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*THEN) (*THEN:NAME)

      This is similar to the "cut group" operator http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      :: from Perl 6. Like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) , this verb always matches, and when backtracked into on failure, it causes the regex engine to try the next alternation in the innermost enclosing group (capturing or otherwise) that has alternations. The two branches of a (?(condition)yes-pattern|no-pattern) do not count as an alternation, as far as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*THEN) is concerned.

      Its name comes from the observation that this operation combined with the alternation operator (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      "|" ) can be used to create what is essentially a pattern-based if/then/else block:

      1.   ( COND (*THEN) FOO | COND2 (*THEN) BAR | COND3 (*THEN) BAZ )

      Note that if this operator is used and NOT inside of an alternation then it acts exactly like the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) operator.

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        / A (*PRUNE) B /

      is the same as

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        / A (*THEN) B /

      but

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        / ( A (*THEN) B | C ) /

      is not the same as

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        / ( A (*PRUNE) B | C ) /

      as after matching the A but failing on the B the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*THEN) verb will backtrack and try C; but the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*PRUNE) verb will simply fail.

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*COMMIT) (*COMMIT:args)

      This is the Perl 6 "commit pattern" http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      <commit> or :::. It's a zero-width pattern similar to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*SKIP) , except that when backtracked into on failure it causes the match to fail outright. No further attempts to find a valid match by advancing the start pointer will occur again. For example,

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

       'aaabaaab' =~ /a+b?(*COMMIT)(?{print "$&\n"; $count++})(*FAIL)/;
 print "Count=$count\n";

      outputs

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

          aaab
    Count=1

      In other words, once the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*COMMIT) has been entered, and if the pattern does not match, the regex engine will not try any further matching on the rest of the string.

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*FAIL) http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*F) (*FAIL:arg)

      This pattern matches nothing and always fails. It can be used to force the engine to backtrack. It is equivalent to (?!), but easier to read. In fact, (?!) gets optimised into http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*FAIL) internally. You can provide an argument so that if the match fails because of this http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      FAIL directive the argument can be obtained from http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $REGERROR .

      It is probably useful only when combined with (?{}) or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (??{}) .

    • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*ACCEPT) (*ACCEPT:arg)

      This pattern matches nothing and causes the end of successful matching at the point at which the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*ACCEPT) pattern was encountered, regardless of whether there is actually more to match in the string. When inside of a nested pattern, such as recursion, or in a subpattern dynamically generated via http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (??{}) , only the innermost pattern is ended immediately.

      If the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*ACCEPT) is inside of capturing groups then the groups are marked as ended at the point at which the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      (*ACCEPT) was encountered. For instance:

      http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

        'AB' =~ /(A (A|B(*ACCEPT)|C) D)(E)/x;

      will match, and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $1 will be http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      AB and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $2 will be http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      B , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $3 will not be set. If another branch in the inner parentheses was matched, such as in the string 'ACDE', then the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      D and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      E would have to be matched as well.

      You can provide an argument, which will be available in the var http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

      perltidy

      $REGMARK after the match completes.

Backtracking

NOTE: This section presents an abstract approximation of regular expression behavior. For a more rigorous (and complicated) view of the rules involved in selecting a match among possible alternatives, see Combining RE Pieces.

A fundamental feature of regular expression matching involves the notion called backtracking, which is currently used (when needed) by all regular non-possessive expression quantifiers, namely http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"*" , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"*?" , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"+" , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"+?" , {n,m}, and {n,m}?. Backtracking is often optimized internally, but the general principle outlined here is valid.

For a regular expression to match, the entire regular expression must match, not just part of it. So if the beginning of a pattern containing a quantifier succeeds in a way that causes later parts in the pattern to fail, the matching engine backs up and recalculates the beginning part--that's why it's called backtracking.

Here is an example of backtracking: Let's say you want to find the word following "foo" in the string "Food is on the foo table.":

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $_ = "Food is on the foo table.";
    if ( /\b(foo)\s+(\w+)/i ) {
        print "$2 follows $1.\n";
    }

When the match runs, the first part of the regular expression (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\b(foo) ) finds a possible match right at the beginning of the string, and loads up http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$1 with "Foo". However, as soon as the matching engine sees that there's no whitespace following the "Foo" that it had saved in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$1 , it realizes its mistake and starts over again one character after where it had the tentative match. This time it goes all the way until the next occurrence of "foo". The complete regular expression matches this time, and you get the expected output of "table follows foo."

Sometimes minimal matching can help a lot. Imagine you'd like to match everything between "foo" and "bar". Initially, you write something like this:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $_ =  "The food is under the bar in the barn.";
    if ( /foo(.*)bar/ ) {
        print "got <$1>\n";
    }

Which perhaps unexpectedly yields:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  got <d is under the bar in the >

That's because .* was greedy, so you get everything between the first "foo" and the last "bar". Here it's more effective to use minimal matching to make sure you get the text between a "foo" and the first "bar" thereafter.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    if ( /foo(.*?)bar/ ) { print "got <$1>\n" }
  got <d is under the >

Here's another example. Let's say you'd like to match a number at the end of a string, and you also want to keep the preceding part of the match. So you write this:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $_ = "I have 2 numbers: 53147";
    if ( /(.*)(\d*)/ ) {                                # Wrong!
        print "Beginning is <$1>, number is <$2>.\n";
    }

That won't work at all, because .* was greedy and gobbled up the whole string. As http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\d* can match on an empty string the complete regular expression matched successfully.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    Beginning is <I have 2 numbers: 53147>, number is <>.

Here are some variants, most of which don't work:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $_ = "I have 2 numbers: 53147";
    @pats = qw{
        (.*)(\d*)
        (.*)(\d+)
        (.*?)(\d*)
        (.*?)(\d+)
        (.*)(\d+)$
        (.*?)(\d+)$
        (.*)\b(\d+)$
        (.*\D)(\d+)$
    };

    for $pat (@pats) {
        printf "%-12s ", $pat;
        if ( /$pat/ ) {
            print "<$1> <$2>\n";
        } else {
            print "FAIL\n";
        }
    }

That will print out:

  1.     (.*)(\d*)    <I have 2 numbers: 53147> <>
  2.     (.*)(\d+)    <I have 2 numbers: 5314> <7>
  3.     (.*?)(\d*)   <> <>
  4.     (.*?)(\d+)   <I have > <2>
  5.     (.*)(\d+)$   <I have 2 numbers: 5314> <7>
  6.     (.*?)(\d+)$  <I have 2 numbers: > <53147>
  7.     (.*)\b(\d+)$ <I have 2 numbers: > <53147>
  8.     (.*\D)(\d+)$ <I have 2 numbers: > <53147>

As you see, this can be a bit tricky. It's important to realize that a regular expression is merely a set of assertions that gives a definition of success. There may be 0, 1, or several different ways that the definition might succeed against a particular string. And if there are multiple ways it might succeed, you need to understand backtracking to know which variety of success you will achieve.

When using lookahead assertions and negations, this can all get even trickier. Imagine you'd like to find a sequence of non-digits not followed by "123". You might try to write that as

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $_ = "ABC123";
    if ( /^\D*(?!123)/ ) {                # Wrong!
        print "Yup, no 123 in $_\n";
    }

But that isn't going to match; at least, not the way you're hoping. It claims that there is no 123 in the string. Here's a clearer picture of why that pattern matches, contrary to popular expectations:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $x = 'ABC123';
    $y = 'ABC445';

    print "1: got $1\n" if $x =~ /^(ABC)(?!123)/;
    print "2: got $1\n" if $y =~ /^(ABC)(?!123)/;

    print "3: got $1\n" if $x =~ /^(\D*)(?!123)/;
    print "4: got $1\n" if $y =~ /^(\D*)(?!123)/;

This prints

  1.     2: got ABC
  2.     3: got AB
  3.     4: got ABC

You might have expected test 3 to fail because it seems to a more general purpose version of test 1. The important difference between them is that test 3 contains a quantifier (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\D* ) and so can use backtracking, whereas test 1 will not. What's happening is that you've asked "Is it true that at the start of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$x , following 0 or more non-digits, you have something that's not 123?" If the pattern matcher had let http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\D* expand to "ABC", this would have caused the whole pattern to fail.

The search engine will initially match http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\D* with "ABC". Then it will try to match (?!123) with "123", which fails. But because a quantifier (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\D* ) has been used in the regular expression, the search engine can backtrack and retry the match differently in the hope of matching the complete regular expression.

The pattern really, really wants to succeed, so it uses the standard pattern back-off-and-retry and lets http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\D* expand to just "AB" this time. Now there's indeed something following "AB" that is not "123". It's "C123", which suffices.

We can deal with this by using both an assertion and a negation. We'll say that the first part in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$1 must be followed both by a digit and by something that's not "123". Remember that the lookaheads are zero-width expressions--they only look, but don't consume any of the string in their match. So rewriting this way produces what you'd expect; that is, case 5 will fail, but case 6 succeeds:

  1.     print "5: got $1\n" if $x =~ /^(\D*)(?=\d)(?!123)/;
  2.     print "6: got $1\n" if $y =~ /^(\D*)(?=\d)(?!123)/;
  4.     6: got ABC

In other words, the two zero-width assertions next to each other work as though they're ANDed together, just as you'd use any built-in assertions: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

/^$/ matches only if you're at the beginning of the line AND the end of the line simultaneously. The deeper underlying truth is that juxtaposition in regular expressions always means AND, except when you write an explicit OR using the vertical bar. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

/ab/ means match "a" AND (then) match "b", although the attempted matches are made at different positions because "a" is not a zero-width assertion, but a one-width assertion.

WARNING: Particularly complicated regular expressions can take exponential time to solve because of the immense number of possible ways they can use backtracking to try for a match. For example, without internal optimizations done by the regular expression engine, this will take a painfully long time to run:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    'aaaaaaaaaaaa' =~ /((a{0,5}){0,5})*[c]/

And if you used http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"*" 's in the internal groups instead of limiting them to 0 through 5 matches, then it would take forever--or until you ran out of stack space. Moreover, these internal optimizations are not always applicable. For example, if you put http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

{0,5} instead of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"*" on the external group, no current optimization is applicable, and the match takes a long time to finish.

A powerful tool for optimizing such beasts is what is known as an "independent group", which does not backtrack (see (?>pattern)). Note also that zero-length lookahead/lookbehind assertions will not backtrack to make the tail match, since they are in "logical" context: only whether they match is considered relevant. For an example where side-effects of lookahead might have influenced the following match, see (?>pattern).

Version 8 Regular Expressions

In case you're not familiar with the "regular" Version 8 regex routines, here are the pattern-matching rules not described above.

Any single character matches itself, unless it is a metacharacter with a special meaning described here or above. You can cause characters that normally function as metacharacters to be interpreted literally by prefixing them with a "\" (e.g., http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"\." matches a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"." , not any character; "\\" matches a "\"). This escape mechanism is also required for the character used as the pattern delimiter.

A series of characters matches that series of characters in the target string, so the pattern http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

blurfl would match "blurfl" in the target string.

You can specify a character class, by enclosing a list of characters in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[] , which will match any character from the list. If the first character after the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"[" is http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"^" , the class matches any character not in the list. Within a list, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"-" character specifies a range, so that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

a-z represents all characters between "a" and "z", inclusive. If you want either http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"-" or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"]" itself to be a member of a class, put it at the start of the list (possibly after a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"^" ), or escape it with a backslash. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"-" is also taken literally when it is at the end of the list, just before the closing http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"]" . (The following all specify the same class of three characters: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[-az] , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[az-] , and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[a\-z] . All are different from http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[a-z] , which specifies a class containing twenty-six characters, even on EBCDIC-based character sets.) Also, if you try to use the character classes http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\w , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\W , \s, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\S , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\d , or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\D as endpoints of a range, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"-" is understood literally.

Note also that the whole range idea is rather unportable between character sets, except for four situations that Perl handles specially. Any subset of the ranges http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[A-Z] , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[a-z] , and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[0-9] are guaranteed to match the expected subset of ASCII characters, no matter what character set the platform is running. The fourth portable way to specify ranges is to use the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\N{...} syntax to specify either end point of the range. For example, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[\N{U+04}-\N{U+07}] means to match the Unicode code points http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\N{U+04} , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\N{U+05} , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\N{U+06} , and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\N{U+07} , whatever their native values may be on the platform. Under use re 'strict' or within a (?[ ]), a warning is raised, if enabled, and the other end point of a range which has a http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\N{...} endpoint is not portably specified. For example,

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

 [\N{U+00}-\x06]    # Warning under "use re 'strict'".

It is hard to understand without digging what exactly matches ranges other than subsets of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[A-Z] , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[a-z] , and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[0-9] . A sound principle is to use only ranges that begin from and end at either alphabetics of equal case ([a-e], [A-E]), or digits ([0-9]). Anything else is unsafe or unclear. If in doubt, spell out the range in full.

Characters may be specified using a metacharacter syntax much like that used in C: "\n" matches a newline, "\t" a tab, "\r" a carriage return, "\f" a form feed, etc. More generally, \nnn, where nnn is a string of three octal digits, matches the character whose coded character set value is nnn. Similarly, \xnn, where nn are hexadecimal digits, matches the character whose ordinal is nn. The expression \cx matches the character control-x. Finally, the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"." metacharacter matches any character except "\n" (unless you use /s).

You can specify a series of alternatives for a pattern using http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"|" to separate them, so that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

fee|fie|foe will match any of "fee", "fie", or "foe" in the target string (as would f(e|i|o)e). The first alternative includes everything from the last pattern delimiter (http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"(" , "(?:", etc. or the beginning of the pattern) up to the first http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"|" , and the last alternative contains everything from the last http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"|" to the next closing pattern delimiter. That's why it's common practice to include alternatives in parentheses: to minimize confusion about where they start and end.

Alternatives are tried from left to right, so the first alternative found for which the entire expression matches, is the one that is chosen. This means that alternatives are not necessarily greedy. For example: when matching http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

foo|foot against "barefoot", only the "foo" part will match, as that is the first alternative tried, and it successfully matches the target string. (This might not seem important, but it is important when you are capturing matched text using parentheses.)

Also remember that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"|" is interpreted as a literal within square brackets, so if you write http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[fee|fie|foe] you're really only matching http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

[feio|] .

Within a pattern, you may designate subpatterns for later reference by enclosing them in parentheses, and you may refer back to the nth subpattern later in the pattern using the metacharacter \n or \gn. Subpatterns are numbered based on the left to right order of their opening parenthesis. A backreference matches whatever actually matched the subpattern in the string being examined, not the rules for that subpattern. Therefore, (0|0x)\d*\s\g1\d* will match "0x1234 0x4321", but not "0x1234 01234", because subpattern 1 matched "0x", even though the rule http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

0|0x could potentially match the leading 0 in the second number.

Warning on http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\1 Instead of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$1

Some people get too used to writing things like:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $pattern =~ s/(\W)/\\\1/g;

This is grandfathered (for \1 to \9) for the RHS of a substitute to avoid shocking the sed addicts, but it's a dirty habit to get into. That's because in PerlThink, the righthand side of an s/// is a double-quoted string. http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\1 in the usual double-quoted string means a control-A. The customary Unix meaning of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\1 is kludged in for s///. However, if you get into the habit of doing that, you get yourself into trouble if you then add an /e modifier.

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    s/(\d+)/ \1 + 1 /eg;            # causes warning under -w

Or if you try to do

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    s/(\d+)/\1000/;

You can't disambiguate that by saying http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\{1}000 , whereas you can fix it with ${1}000. The operation of interpolation should not be confused with the operation of matching a backreference. Certainly they mean two different things on the left side of the s///.

Repeated Patterns Matching a Zero-length Substring

WARNING: Difficult material (and prose) ahead. This section needs a rewrite.

Regular expressions provide a terse and powerful programming language. As with most other power tools, power comes together with the ability to wreak havoc.

A common abuse of this power stems from the ability to make infinite loops using regular expressions, with something as innocuous as:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    'foo' =~ m{ ( o? )* }x;

The o? matches at the beginning of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

'foo' , and since the position in the string is not moved by the match, o? would match again and again because of the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"*" quantifier. Another common way to create a similar cycle is with the looping modifier http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

//g :

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    @matches = ( 'foo' =~ m{ o? }xg );

or

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    print "match: <$&>\n" while 'foo' =~ m{ o? }xg;

or the loop implied by split().

However, long experience has shown that many programming tasks may be significantly simplified by using repeated subexpressions that may match zero-length substrings. Here's a simple example being:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    @chars = split //, $string;           # // is not magic in split
    ($whitewashed = $string) =~ s/()/ /g; # parens avoid magic s// /

Thus Perl allows such constructs, by forcefully breaking the infinite loop. The rules for this are different for lower-level loops given by the greedy quantifiers http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

*+{} , and for higher-level ones like the /g modifier or split() operator.

The lower-level loops are interrupted (that is, the loop is broken) when Perl detects that a repeated expression matched a zero-length substring. Thus

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

   m{ (?: NON_ZERO_LENGTH | ZERO_LENGTH )* }x;

is made equivalent to

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

   m{ (?: NON_ZERO_LENGTH )* (?: ZERO_LENGTH )? }x;

For example, this program

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

   #!perl -l
   "aaaaab" =~ /
          (?:
                a                 # non-zero
                |                 # or
              (?{print "hello"}) # print hello whenever this
                                                    #    branch is tried
              (?=(b))            # zero-width assertion
          )*  # any number of times
        /x;
   print $&;
   print $1;

prints

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

   hello
   aaaaa
   b

Notice that "hello" is only printed once, as when Perl sees that the sixth iteration of the outermost (?:)* matches a zero-length string, it stops the http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"*" .

The higher-level loops preserve an additional state between iterations: whether the last match was zero-length. To break the loop, the following match after a zero-length match is prohibited to have a length of zero. This prohibition interacts with backtracking (see Backtracking), and so the second best match is chosen if the best match is of zero length.

For example:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    $_ = 'bar';
    s/\w??/<$&>/g;

results in http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy
