<><b><><a><><r><> . At each position of the string the best match given by non-greedy http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

?? is the zero-length match, and the second best match is what is matched by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\w . Thus zero-length matches alternate with one-character-long matches.

Similarly, for repeated m/()/g the second-best match is the match at the position one notch further in the string.

The additional state of being matched with zero-length is associated with the matched string, and is reset by each assignment to pos(). Zero-length matches at the end of the previous match are ignored during split.

Combining RE Pieces

Each of the elementary pieces of regular expressions which were described before (such as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

ab or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\Z ) could match at most one substring at the given position of the input string. However, in a typical regular expression these elementary pieces are combined into more complicated patterns using combining operators http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

ST , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

S|T , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

S* etc. (in these examples http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

S and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

T are regular subexpressions).

Such combinations can include alternatives, leading to a problem of choice: if we match a regular expression http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

a|ab against http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"abc" , will it match substring http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"a" or http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

"ab" ? One way to describe which substring is actually matched is the concept of backtracking (see Backtracking). However, this description is too low-level and makes you think in terms of a particular implementation.

Another description starts with notions of "better"/"worse". All the substrings which may be matched by the given regular expression can be sorted from the "best" match to the "worst" match, and it is the "best" match which is chosen. This substitutes the question of "what is chosen?" by the question of "which matches are better, and which are worse?".

Again, for elementary pieces there is no such question, since at most one match at a given position is possible. This section describes the notion of better/worse for combining operators. In the description below http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

S and http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

T are regular subexpressions.

  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    ST

    Consider two possible matches, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    AB and A'B', http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    A and A' are substrings which can be matched by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    B and B' are substrings which can be matched by http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    T .

    If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    A is a better match for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S than A', http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    AB is a better match than A'B'.

    If http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    A and A' coincide: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    AB is a better match than AB' if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    B is a better match for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    T than B'.

  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S|T

    When http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S can match, it is a better match than when only http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    T can match.

    Ordering of two matches for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S is the same as for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S . Similar for two matches for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    T .

  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S{REPEAT_COUNT}

    Matches as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    SSS...S (repeated as many times as necessary).

  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S{min,max}

    Matches as S{max}|S{max-1}|...|S{min+1}|S{min}.

  • S{min,max}?

    Matches as S{min}|S{min+1}|...|S{max-1}|S{max}.

  • S?, http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S* , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S+

    Same as http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S{0,1} , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S{0,BIG_NUMBER} , http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S{1,BIG_NUMBER} respectively.

  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S?? , S*?, S+?

    Same as S{0,1}?, S{0,BIG_NUMBER}?, S{1,BIG_NUMBER}? respectively.

  • (?>S)

    Matches the best match for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S and only that.

  • (?=S), (?<=S)

    Only the best match for http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S is considered. (This is important only if http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S has capturing parentheses, and backreferences are used somewhere else in the whole regular expression.)

  • (?!S), (?<!S)

    For this grouping operator there is no need to describe the ordering, since only whether or not http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    S can match is important.

  • http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    (??{ EXPR }) , (?PARNO)

    The ordering is the same as for the regular expression which is the result of EXPR, or the pattern contained by capture group PARNO.

  • (?(condition)yes-pattern|no-pattern)

    Recall that which of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    yes-pattern or no-pattern actually matches is already determined. The ordering of the matches is the same as for the chosen subexpression.

The above recipes describe the ordering of matches at a given position. One more rule is needed to understand how a match is determined for the whole regular expression: a match at an earlier position is always better than a match at a later position.

Creating Custom RE Engines

As of Perl 5.10.0, one can create custom regular expression engines. This is not for the faint of heart, as they have to plug in at the C level. See perlreapi for more details.

As an alternative, overloaded constants (see overload) provide a simple way to extend the functionality of the RE engine, by substituting one pattern for another.

Suppose that we want to enable a new RE escape-sequence http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\Y| which matches at a boundary between whitespace characters and non-whitespace characters. Note that http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

(?=\S)(?<!\S)|(?!\S)(?<=\S) matches exactly at these positions, so we want to have each http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\Y| in the place of the more complicated version. We can create a module http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

customre to do this:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    package customre;
    use overload;

    sub import {
      shift;
      die "No argument to customre::import allowed" if @_;
      overload::constant 'qr' => \&convert;
    }

    sub invalid { die "/$_[0]/: invalid escape '\\$_[1]'"}

    # We must also take care of not escaping the legitimate \\Y|
    # sequence, hence the presence of '\\' in the conversion rules.
    my %rules = ( '\\' => '\\\\',
                  'Y|' => qr/(?=\S)(?<!\S)|(?!\S)(?<=\S)/ );
    sub convert {
      my $re = shift;
      $re =~ s{
                                \\ ( \\ | Y . )
                            }
                            { $rules{$1} or invalid($re,$1) }sgex;
      return $re;
    }

Now http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

use customre enables the new escape in constant regular expressions, i.e., those without any runtime variable interpolations. As documented in overload, this conversion will work only over literal parts of regular expressions. For http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\Y|$re\Y| the variable part of this regular expression needs to be converted explicitly (but only if the special meaning of http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

\Y| should be enabled inside http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

$re ):

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

    use customre;
    $re = <>;
    chomp $re;
    $re = customre::convert $re;
    /\Y|$re\Y|/;

Embedded Code Execution Frequency

The exact rules for how often (??{}) and (?{}) are executed in a pattern are unspecified. In the case of a successful match you can assume that they DWIM and will be executed in left to right order the appropriate number of times in the accepting path of the pattern as would any other meta-pattern. How non-accepting pathways and match failures affect the number of times a pattern is executed is specifically unspecified and may vary depending on what optimizations can be applied to the pattern and is likely to change from version to version.

For instance in

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  "aaabcdeeeee"=~/a(?{print "a"})b(?{print "b"})cde/;

the exact number of times "a" or "b" are printed out is unspecified for failure, but you may assume they will be printed at least once during a successful match, additionally you may assume that if "b" is printed, it will be preceded by at least one "a".

In the case of branching constructs like the following:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  /a(b|(?{ print "a" }))c(?{ print "c" })/;

you can assume that the input "ac" will output "ac", and that "abc" will output only "c".

When embedded code is quantified, successful matches will call the code once for each matched iteration of the quantifier. For example:

http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy

  "good" =~ /g(?:o(?{print "o"}))*d/;

will output "o" twice.

PCRE/Python Support

As of Perl 5.10.0, Perl supports several Python/PCRE-specific extensions to the regex syntax. While Perl programmers are encouraged to use the Perl-specific syntax, the following are also accepted:

  • (?P<NAME>pattern)

    Define a named capture group. Equivalent to (?<NAME>pattern).

  • (?P=NAME)

    Backreference to a named capture group. Equivalent to http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

    perltidy

    \g{NAME} .

  • (?P>NAME)

    Subroutine call to a named capture group. Equivalent to (?&NAME).

BUGS

There are a number of issues with regard to case-insensitive matching in Unicode rules. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> perltidy

perltidy
